evidence.pdf_reference: TiO 2 aerogels using a 300 W power-tunable Xe lamp as light source.The photocatalytic reaction was carried out in a cylindrical quartz glass reactor (300 mL in volume and 55 mm in diameter) equipped with a magnetic stirrer.The out layer of the reactor is a jacket of flowing water to remove the irradiated heat.In all experiments, 0.1 g of catalyst powder was dispersed in 150 mL of 0.2 M EDA aqueous solution.The suspension was purged with CO 2 for 30 min prior to irradiation.Then, CO 2 was continually flowed

Developing an efficient photocatalyst to reduce CO 2 to methanol is still a major challenge.In this paper, the Fe 3 -doped TiO 2 aerogels were prepared by sol-gel process.Implantation of Fe 3 into TiO 2 lattice can not only narrow the band gap of electron transfer, but also suppress the recombination of photogenerated electron-hole pairs.However, when the doping content of Fe 3 was increased to 5 mol , partial Fe 3 ions may enter into the lattice gap and decrease the stability of the excited electrons.The

the Fe-TiO 2 aerogels can photocatalize reduction of CO 2 in water to aerogel exhibited an enhanced catalytic performance, which was contributable to high porosity of the aerogel materials.Furthermore, the methanol yield was greatly enhanced over 1Fe-TiO 2 and 3Fe-TiO 2 aerogels due to the prolonged lifetime of the excited electrons and the enhanced absorption of the visible light under visible light irradiation.Although the 5Fe-TiO 2 aerogel had the narrowest band gap, the corresponding catalytic

of the excited electrons.The UV-Vis diffuse reflectance spectra, photoluminescence (PL) spectra, and UV-excited photoelectron spectroscopy (UPS) were used to study the effect of the Fe 3 doping amount on the photoelectric properties of the aerogels.The photocatalytic conversion of CO 2 to methanol was used to evaluate their catalytic performances upon illumination by a 300 W Xe lamp.

electrons 18,33.However, the PL intensity increased as the doping amount reached 5 mol .There are two ways for Fe 3 to present into TiO 2 crystal, substitution of Ti in lattice or presence in lattice gap.When Fe 3 locates in the lattice of TiO 2 , Fe 3 behaves as an electron donor to provide one electron for the catalyst. When the doping content of Fe 3 was 5 mol , partial Fe 3 ions entered into the lattice gap and played the role of acceptor impurity, thus leading to a relatively faster recombination rate

evidence.pdf_reference: TiO 2 aerogels using a 300 W power-tunable Xe lamp as light source.The photocatalytic reaction was carried out in a cylindrical quartz glass reactor (300 mL in volume and 55 mm in diameter) equipped with a magnetic stirrer.The out layer of the reactor is a jacket of flowing water to remove the irradiated heat.In all experiments, 0.1 g of catalyst powder was dispersed in 150 mL of 0.2 M EDA aqueous solution.The suspension was purged with CO 2 for 30 min prior to irradiation.Then, CO 2 was continually flowed

CO 2 was continually flowed through the reactor at a rate of 20 mL min.In each sampling, 2 mL of liquid sample was collected from the reactor by a syringe with a Teflon filter to remove solid particles.The concentration of methanol was quantitatively analyzed by gas chromatography.The sample was analyzed using PERSEE G5 gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector and KB-wax capillary column (30 m, 0.53 mm, and 1.00 m).The concentrations of methanol were determined using standard calibration

using standard calibration curve of peak area versus concentration (Figs.S1 andS2).Each sample was measured three times, and their mean values were reported as the final data.The methanol yield 23 was calculated based on the below equation: where Y CH 3 OH (molg) is the methanol yield, C CH 3 OH (molmL) is the concentration of methanol, and V reactant (mL) and M catalyst (g) are the volume of the EDA aqueous solution and the mass of catalysts, respectively.

at 50 C for 48 h to form solid gel.The solid gel was soaked with 80 mL of EtOHH 2 O solution (VV 1) for 24 h.Then, the liquid was poured out, and the solid gel was sequentially soaked with 80 mL of TEOSEtOH (VV 1) and 80 mL of EtOH in the same way.After that, the solid gel and 70 mL of fresh EtOH was placed in a high-pressure reactor.Temperature programmed to 220 at 3 Cmin for 1.5 h, and followed by slow deflation.After cooling down, the sample was taken out and calcined at 450 C in air for 10 h.Four

of the excited electrons.The UV-Vis diffuse reflectance spectra, photoluminescence (PL) spectra, and UV-excited photoelectron spectroscopy (UPS) were used to study the effect of the Fe 3 doping amount on the photoelectric properties of the aerogels.The photocatalytic conversion of CO 2 to methanol was used to evaluate their catalytic performances upon illumination by a 300 W Xe lamp.
